description: Basic principles of protein characterization, enzyme kinetics and mechanism, membrane structure and function, metabolism and biochemistry of energy, and signal transduction. A problem-solving approach will be employed and emphasis will be placed on the application of quantitative methods to biochemical problems. Each of the five major sections of the course will be concluded with group discussions specifically directed at the solution of numerical problems and the interpretation of experimental results. name: BIOCHEMISTRY

values.comments:
BIOL402 covers basic principles of protein characterization, enzyme kinetics and
mechanism, membrane structure and function, metabolism and biochemistry of energy,
and signal transduction. The course applies a problem-solving approach and emphasizes
application of quantitative methods to biochemical problems. Each of the five major
sections of the course are concluded with group discussions specifically directed at the
solution of numerical problems and the interpretation of experimental results. To
maximize opportunities for critical, analytical, and creative thinking, a majority of the
material is tested in the form of take-home examinations. Sessions during which
discussions of original literature take place are optional.
Students generally felt they learned a lot from the course. The class expects
students to take three in-class exams, two take-home tests, and write a three thousandword
journal paper. Thus, the majority of the learning experience comes from these
evaluations. One student especially appreciated that the “take home exams put a unique,
clinical perspective on the class,” which was helpful for students planning to pursue a
medical degree.
Professor Sanders received mostly positive reviews. One student said that he “is
an amazing teacher who goes out of his way to help the students.” Another liked that he
was “genuinely enthusiastic” and extremely “understanding.” Other students felt that he
could be “boring” at times, mostly because the course covered a great deal of material. In
general, Professor Sanders appeared to be readily available to answer questions and
willing to discuss topics that move beyond the scope of the class.
Because this is specifically the LPS section, the class was composed of part-time
or pre-medical students. Students found the class quite rigorous with the large number of
difficult and lengthy exams.
